snifc.sensor
Interface SensorIfc

public interface SensorIfc

A sensor interface, represents the interface of a sensor. A sensor is the main part of the network of sensor. It is composed of a Memory, a Queue , a Captor and an IOPorts. It is a container for all these elements. The simulator triggers hooks methods of the sensor, and each method is forwarded to the correspond sensor's element. All hook methods are called in that order in each step of the simulation - simulateCapture() - activateCaptor() - activatePort() - activateQueue() - toString() method is called for statistical purpose

Author:
sfrenot
See Also:
MemoryIfc, QueueIfc, CaptorIfc, IOPortsIfc

Method Summary

          activateCaptor is forwarded to the inner captor

          That method simulates the main function of the sensor.

          That method is called only in the setup phase.
 void simulateCapture()
          simulateCapture, triggers a randomizer that position a boolean to know if the captor generates a new capture or not.
 

Method Detail

simulateCapture

public void simulateCapture()
simulateCapture, triggers a randomizer that position a boolean to know if the captor generates a new capture or not. The method is forwarded to the captor.

activateCaptor

public void activateCaptor()
activateCaptor is forwarded to the inner captor

activatePort

public void activatePort()
The incoming packets are queued after the captor. Every packet on each link is get and eventually put in the queue.

activateQueue

public void activateQueue()
That method simulates the main function of the sensor. The activateQueue concretize the following actions. It deQueues the next Packet, (@see QueueIfc#deQueue() it tries to store the packet, (@see Memory#store(PacketIfc) if the packet is valid, it is transmited of the links (@see IOPorts#writePacket(Packet)

getPort

public IOPortsIfc getPort()
That method is called only in the setup phase.

Returns:
the IOPorts representing that Sensor
